DOCNAME: BRADEŠKO AND RUTAR MARKETING D.O.O. v. SLOVENIA
JUDGES: André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Ann Power-Forde;Helena Jäderblom;Mark Villiger;Paul Lemmens
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The applicant company , ORG , is a limited liability company registered in GPE . They were represented before the ORG by PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , lawyers practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , ORG Attorney .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicant is the director of ORG , which is a furniture store owned by the applicant company .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE ORG of GPE ( hereinafter referred to as “ the Inspectorate ” ) carried out inspections at FAC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG issued a decision stating that the applicant company had failed to pay interest to customers who had put down an advance deposit to reserve their orders with the store . The decision illustrated the applicant company ’s practice by listing CARDINAL examples which concerned in total MONEY ( ORG ) . It was found guilty of violating section CARDINAL of LAW . In addition , the applicant was found guilty of failing to fulfil his supervisory role so as to prevent the above violation from occurring . The applicant company was fined approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL and the applicant approximately ORG CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicants made an application for judicial review in which they alleged that the ORG had wrongly established the facts ; in particular , they argued that by signing a contract which included the general terms and conditions of purchase , the customers had waived their statutory right to the payment of interest . The applicants contended that the ORG should have checked with each individual customer whether they had waived the right to the payment of such interest before imposing the fines . Consequently , they alleged that the relevant law had been wrongly applied and requested that ordinary court proceedings be opened .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , in summary proceedings ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , delivered a judgment rejecting the application for judicial review as unfounded . Referring to the ORG ’s decision , reports of the ORG concerning the aforementioned inspections , a written statement by the applicant company of DATE relating to one of those reports ( dated DATE ) , and a report the ORG had drawn up after the application for judicial review had been made , the court found that the facts had been properly established by the ORG and that the application was unfounded . In particular , the court observed that the rights enjoyed by the consumers by virtue of LAW could not be excluded or limited by contract . Moreover , it found that the customers had not been given the option to pay for the goods in full on delivery . The applicant company was ordered to pay ORG CARDINAL and the applicant LAW in court fees . The judgment , which included an instruction that there would be no right of appeal , was served on them on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants requested to ORG to lodge a request for the protection of legality ( extraordinary appeal ) before ORG . They argued , in particular , that the sanction had been disproportionate and unlawful . As regards the latter , they argued that the minimum fines prescribed for the offence in question had been reduced to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL for a company and LAW for an individual by LAW to LAW , which had entered into force on DATE . The court , in their submission , had failed to take that into account and to impose a lower fine in accordance with the legislation or , alternatively , give the applicants a right of appeal against the judgment which , under LAW , was permitted in cases where the fine imposed was higher than the minimum fine prescribed . The applicants made no complaints with regard to the lack of an oral hearing before the local court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG replied to the applicants , informing them that he had no intention of lodging a request for the protection of legality in their case . He explained that although they were correct in arguing that a lower fine should have been imposed on them in line with the amended LAW , their case was not important enough for the development of jurisprudence , nor had they argued that it had had any serious consequences for them .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Consumer Protection Act reads , in its relevant part , as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) If the company expressly or implicitly provides for the purchase of goods or services subject to a full or partial deposit and delivers the goods or service after the receipt of that deposit , it is obliged to pay ... interest to the customer ... ”
Section CARDINAL provides , in so far as relevant :
“ ( CARDINAL ) ... a company shall be issued with a fine of CARDINAL [ approximately LAW ] and CARDINAL NORP tolars if :
CARDINAL . it does not specify in the final invoice , and pay the customer , the interest due on the deposit paid at the interest rate ... ( section CARDINAL ) ;

( CARDINAL ) As punishment for the offence mentioned in the preceding paragraph , the director of the company ... shall be issued with a fine of CARDINAL [ approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ] and CARDINAL NORP tolars . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW to the Customer Protection Act , which entered into force on DATE , amended section CARDINAL as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) ... a company shall be issued with a fine of between ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL and ORG CARDINAL if :
( CARDINAL ) As punishment for the offence mentioned in the preceding paragraph , the director of the company ... shall be issued with a fine of between ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL and ORG CARDINAL . ”

CARDINAL . For details of the relevant provisions of LAW , in particular those concerning “ summary proceedings ” , see NORP v. GPE ( ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) . As regards the right of appeal in such proceedings ‒ an issue of particular relevance to the present case ‒ section CARDINAL ) reads , in so far as relevant , as follows :
“ An appeal may be lodged against ... decisions of the court of first instance ... in cases where the fine imposed was higher than the minimum fine prescribed for that offence ... ”
Such an appeal may be lodged on any grounds , except points of fact .

CARDINAL . A request for the protection of legality is an extraordinary appeal that may be lodged by ORG , either proprio motu or on the initiative of a party to the proceedings or another person entitled to do so under LAW , against any final judicial decision issued in the minor offences proceedings . It can be used to complain about a violation of the rules of substantive or procedural law . These requests are dealt with by a CARDINAL - member panel of ORG .

CARDINAL . The DATE Amendment to LAW , which entered into force on DATE , limits the availability of constitutional appeals by , inter alia , excluding in principle the possibility to challenge decisions issued in proceedings concerning minor offences . However , in exceptional circumstances such cases can be examined if they raise an important constitutional question extending beyond that particular case . The relevant provisions of the LAW read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A constitutional appeal shall not be admissible if the violation of human rights or fundamental freedoms [ alleged ] did not have significant consequences for the complainant .
( CARDINAL ) It is deemed that there has been no violation of human rights or fundamental freedoms having significant consequences for the complainant with regard to individual decisions :
- issued in small - claims disputes ... ;
- concerning costs of proceedings , where such decision alone is challenged in the constitutional appeal ;
- issued in trespass to property disputes ;
- issued in minor offence cases .

( CARDINAL ) Irrespective of the preceding paragraph , ORG may in particularly justified cases decide exceptionally on a constitutional appeal against the individual decisions referred to in the preceding paragraph , notably where the decision appealed against concerns an important constitutional question which goes beyond the importance of the actual case . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) A constitutional appeal shall be rejected :
- if it does not concern an individual act by which a state authority , local authority , or a holder of public power decided on the rights , obligations or legal interest of the complainant ;
- if the complainant does not have a legal interest in a decision on the constitutional appeal ;
- if it is not admissible , except in the instance referred to in the third paragraph of the preceding section ;
- if it was not lodged in due time ;
( CARDINAL ) A constitutional appeal shall be accepted for consideration :
- if there has been a violation of human rights or fundamental freedoms which has had significant consequences for the complainant ; or
- if it concerns an important constitutional question which goes beyond the importance of the actual case .

CARDINAL . ORG held in its decision no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE that the guarantees of a fair trial applicable to criminal proceedings should , in principle , also apply to minor offences proceedings , in particular as regards the right of the accused to participate in the proceedings and express their views on all relevant factual and legal issues . The court ’s views were confirmed on a number of occasions in its subsequent case - law , notably in decision no . Up-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , in which it found that the applicant should have been given the opportunity to exonerate himself from the charges by producing a witness who could confirm that he had not been present at the scene of the minor offence at the time it had been committed .
CARDINAL . In that decision ORG explicitly stated :

“ Regardless of the fact that the court is not obliged to accept all the evidence submitted by the defence , it must accept the evidence which is relevant from the perspective of substantive law and for which the defence has shown with a sufficient degree of probability that it exists and is legally relevant . The court may dismiss evidence submitted if taking further evidence is redundant because the case is clear , if the fact to be proved by the evidence submitted has already been proved or has no influence on the case , or if the means of evidence are unsuitable or unattainable . ”

CARDINAL . Moreover , in decision no . Up-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE the court found a violation of the LAW on the grounds that the local court had refused to hold an oral hearing , which had deprived the applicant of an opportunity to have examined the incriminating witnesses on whose statements the decision had been based . Similar issues were also examined in another recent decision , no . Up-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE . Finally , decision no . Up-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , also adopted under the new admissibility criteria , included , inter alia , an examination of the penalty imposed for the minor offence in question .
